text: - Hello everyone.
This demo will cover how

to activate Amazon Guard
Duty ECS Runtime Monitoring
for instances running on Fargate.

This protection plan extends
your runtime threat detection

to Amazon Elastic Container
Service, Amazon ECS

workloads running on Amazon
Elastic Compute Cloud
EC2 instances.

And on AWS Fargate Guard duty
is a threat detection service

that protects your AWS
accounts, workloads,

and data by continuously
monitoring AWS log
and networking activity

to identify malicious
behavior using machine
learning anomaly detection.

And AWS developed an
industry leading third
party threat intelligence.

- Amazon ECS is a fully
managed container orchestration

service that helps customers
more efficiently deploy,

manage, and scale
containerized applications.

Guardee supports ECS deployments
running on Amazon EC2
as well as fargate.

Amazon EC2 delivers secure,
reliable, high-performance
and cost-effective compute infrastructure.

West Fargate is a serverless
compute engine for containers
that works with Amazon ECS
and Amazon Elastic Kubernetes EKS.

Amazon ECS is secure by
design with resource isolation
and native integration with AWS security,
identity management and governance tools.

However, like any compute
workload container applications
can run potentially vulnerable software

or be misconfigured leaving
them susceptible to attack

guard duty ECS Runtime
monitoring deploys a
lightweight, fully managed

- Security agent that analyzes
operating system level
behavior such as file access, process

- Execution,
- And network connections.

- Guard duty combines the
newly added runtime visibility
with existing control plane

and network visibility to
help customers identify

and respond to threats
targeting applications

and data running in
containerized workloads.

- Guard duty ECS Runtime
monitoring allows security
and application teams
to uniquely detect sophisticated attacks
that can occur across containers,
underlying compute resources,

and more broadly throughout
a containerized environment.

A modern security event
could start with a compromise

of a single container running
a vulnerable web application

with access permissions
to underlying compute
or Amazon ECS task resources

where misconfigured
credentials could allow
for broader access to the account

and ultimately the valuable
data stored within it.

Guard duty ECS runtime
monitoring can be enabled

with a few clicks in the guard
duty console leveraging a DS
organizations for multi account management
and ECS for automated resource discovery
and agent deployment.

Now the switch to the console
for a brief demonstration,

- Runtime
- Monitoring can be enabled for a
- Standalone account or being able

to monitor multiple accounts
within your environment.
To start off, we are going

to enable runtime monitoring
for a standalone account.

So we've navigated to
the guard duty console

and selected runtime
monitoring within the left
hand navigation panel.
If we go under the configuration tab
and scroll down, you'll have choices
to enable runtime monitoring.
First we will select runtime monitoring
and this will enable runtime monitoring.
For this account, select confirm,

and now that that is enabled,
as we can see from the banner
above, we want

to enable ECS runtime
monitoring specifically.
So if you also wanted,

we're interested in enable
Amazon EKAS runtime,
you can enable that here.

But for this demonstration, we
are only enabling AWS Fargate
for ECS only runtime configuration,
and we'll simply select enable
and confirm that we do want
to have the automated agent configuration

for a OS Fargate ECS
only for this account.

And now runtime monitoring
has been enabled. Now

- Let's go over how to
enable runtime monitoring
for multiple account environments.
So we're still in the guard duty console.

We're underneath the Runtime
Monitoring protection plan,

but this time we have
logged into the Delegated

Administrator account,
a foreign organization.
So in a multiple account environment,

only the guard duty Delegated
Administrator account can

enable or disable runtime
monitoring for member accounts.

So as we slow down under runtime
monitoring configuration,
we see that we have a few more options.
So let's select edit.

So the first step is to
enable runtime monitoring.
And you have two options.

We can see that configure
accounts manually has been

preselected and so this is
in case you would only want
to enable runtime monitoring

for very selective accounts
within your organizational unit,

such as your delegated
administrative account,
which you can easily decide to only enable

or disable runtime
monitoring for that account.
You can also decide whether

or not you want to automatically
enable runtime monitoring
for new member accounts.

This would mean that all
member accounts that are added

to this specific organizational
unit will automatically have
runtime monitoring enabled.

You also have the option
to enable for all accounts.

And so all accounts that currently
have guard duty activated
and are are in your organization.

They will automatically have
runtime monitoring enabled

and all future member
accounts will have it
automatically enabled as well.

We are gonna select Enable for
all accounts for this demo.
Then we want to scroll down

to the automated agent
configuration for a WSS Fargate.

So you see that you have
these same options as you did
above, giving you the ability

to either configure the
automated agent configuration

for very selective accounts
within the organizational unit,

or automatically enable
for all accounts in order

to have full coverage and not
have to worry about whether
or not new accounts have the
automated agent configuration enabled.

We are gonna enable for
all accounts for this demo
and then select save.

Now that you have runtime
monitoring enabled for Amazon ECS,
you can navigate to runtime coverage

and underneath ECS
cluster runtime coverage,

you have the ability to
see the coverage statistics

for your AWS Fargate
resources that are associated

with your own accounts
or your member accounts.
And it shows the percentage of healthy
Amazon ECS clusters over all

of the Amazon ECS clusters
in the selected region.

Now that we have guard duty
runtime monitoring enabled

for a DS Fargate, let's
look at a few findings.
So I've navigated

to the finding section
within the guard duty console

and here under resource
type I've already filtered
for the ECS clusters.
And as we scroll down,

we can take a look at this
cryptocurrency finding.
So I'm gonna select the finding.
We are going to be

provided with a bit more context,
so you have your overview
information about the region severity,
but as we scroll down,
we can also see some ECS cluster details.
So you have the task ID

as well as the specific
name of the ECS cluster.
You also have the specific container.

So this is going to help
when your task has multiple
containers associated with it
to really pinpoint which container.

You also have information on
the tags as well as action
as you scroll down a bit more.
You also see under runtime details,
you have process level information.

So this is going to give
you the executable path.

You also have the hash
associated with this finding.

So this is something that you
can run against known virus
or malware databases,

and you also have the
ability to see all lineage.

And that's just gonna provide
you a bit more information on
how this threat got into your container.
Now if we switch over

and let's look at this
execution runtime reverse shell.
This is another finding.

It's you're going to have
the same information given,

but if we scroll down to that
process level information

that we've been provided,
now you have the name

of the binary and the
associated ex executable path,
and you can also see the lineage.

And here we have three different
levels, thus providing you

with more information on
how this finding came to be.
We can select level three,
which is the earliest line of lineage.

We can see we have the start
time name space process,
as well as the executable path.
When we go to level two, we can see

that there was a bash
associated with the finding.
And level one you have the binary file.
So all of this information

that you're given on the
guard duty runtime monitoring

findings related to ECS
clusters, it's going to allow you
to respond faster
and with a lot more precision
to threats detected within your account.

- In this video, we demonstrated
the guard duty runtime

protection for ECS
feature to teach you how
to expand your runtime threat detection

for a CS workloads
running on EC2 instances
and on a DS Fargate.
For more information and

to try guard duty EECS
runtime monitoring at no cost
for 30 days, please visit
www.aws.amazon.com/guard duty.
